After several drive-bys, we went in on Sunday around 2 pm.  We were seated immediately and pored over the extensive menu.  The boy ended up with one of the specials, a chorizo skillet.  I got a skillet with spinach, tomato, and cheese, eggs poached.   The eggs were done to perfection.  The skillet was tasty, but I thought the hashbrowns were more like potatoes than hashbrowns--mushy.  The ingredients seemed fresh, but were a little bland, even after a generous application of hot sauce. One major coup: they have turkey sausage!  As a non-pork eater, having zero breakfast meat options is one of the greatest perils. Two skillets with pancakes, a side of turkey sausage, and two glasses or orange juice: $30ish, including tip.

By far my favorite breakfast place.  It is clean, great service, good prices, nice portions and down the street from me.  Sundays are definietely their busy days, but that's the day they serve their delicious chicken and rice cream soup, so we mostly go their on Sundays.  Actually, who am i kidding we go there all the time.  Now I'm not a huge pancake fan (I know, I know), but their pancakes are on point! After the 30 millionth time my bf hounded me to just have some, I did and now I know why he wants to always go there. Everything on the breakfast menu is great. Highly, highly recommend you ditch Ihop, golden nugget, denny's or wherever else and come here =)

Clean, huge menu, friendly and attentive service. Very reasonably priced. Like mentioned before, not "gourmet" but definitely a solid breakfast joint (and I saw a nice looking club sandwich last time I was there, so probably a good lunch spot too). BTW, the hash browns are unsalted, so be prepared to flavor that business.

Has never been the same since my first stop by. My Bf and I have frequented to try other things on the menu and never seem to be impressed with anything else the same way the pancakes won our heart. Here are as follows  + soup hasn't failed yet so far. Chicken and rice soup was awesome. Creamy and filling. Nowhere near bland. Tomato with barley soup - a creamy tomato base and the barley soft. Also really good. - Serving-size spoons (pretty thick and heavy) for your soup.  +eggs florentine. Think eggs benedict, minus the ham. Add spinach.  Made pretty well. The English muffin doesn't hold up to egg yolk well though. I would have liked a slight toast on em. Otherwise, delicious, and yum. - Cobb salad. Simple..... ice berg lettuce a little watery for the salad. Chicken and bacon done well.  Otherwise nothing too special. Bleu cheese dressing did ok, but with watery lettuce, it didn't really hold.  Pretty forgettable. - chorizo skillet. Looked like a hot mess. Didn't taste like much. Just looked like a red, greasy, mish mash of eggy meatloaf texture. Not so appetizing. In conclusion, I'd say stick with the breakfast items.  Pancakes, hash browns, and eggs.  These won't disappoint. There's a few combos they offer to include breakfast items...  like 2x2x2, plus bacon/sausage/or not... etc etc.  Any other selections, that's your call =).   In terms of service, it's decent  if you don't mind being called "kids"  all day by certain waitresses.

Quite possibly the best French Toast I have ever had. My grandmother and I stopped in for some breakfast and it was delicious and it had HUGE portions. I'd definitely recommend the French Toast. Everyone there was really friendly and the owner even walked around making sure everyone was ok.

Okay so anyone who knows me knows I love breakfast.  I have been known to become giddy at the sight of pancakes.  Alps did not disappoint me one little bit.  What I found to be more enjoyable was the friendliness of everyone that I came across.  It appears to be family owned and they have staff that have been with them for years.  I mean let's be honest, you can get really good breakfast many place but the service here is AWESOME!  They may see me on Saturday AND Sunday mornings. :-)

Alps West is the second reincarnation of a diner that for a time was the location of a bank, a Washington Mutual, before reverting back to a diner. I never got a chance to eat at the original Alps West, which is a shame because I've known about its existence way back in the day. How far back? Yellow school bus back. But as luck would have it, what ended up bad for WaMu, turned out to be good for Alps. Anyhow, back to the present. My friend and I stopped here for late lunch. We were both surprised how big the dining space is. I don't know how big the original Alps West was, but the place was very airy. The place was over half full of people when we arrived. Mainly regulars, who appeared to be on a first name basis with the staff. Still it was a nice balance of older, neighborhood folks, with young couples, and a few solo diners reading their papers or smart-phones. We were seated in a comfy booth by the window and promptly ordered coffee before the menus even hit the table. We both ended up having our standard breakfast fare. Pancakes, sausage links, scrambled eggs, and hash browns.  Our food came out super fast. The links were tasty, definitely more than a few steps above your generic diner special. The pancakes were slightly on the dry side, but nothing a few pats of butter and syrup couldn't solve. Eat your hashbrowns quickly, as they taste mushy when cold. But to our horror, the scrambled eggs were made from egg mix. Major downer in my book. Even the "cheapest" diners I've eaten at use actual eggs. On the other hand, the coffee was good. Yes, coffee is an important part of the diner experience and this one passes. The rest of the menu looks promising. My friend wants to try the pork chops, I saw a few sandwiches and omlettes that look appealing. We will be back. Pros: Wide menu variety, good coffee, reasonable prices, reasonable seating area, parking lot available across the alley behind the building, good coffee, friendly feel of staff and regulars, the ambience...it's weird sitting in place that a few years ago was still a bank. The interior still has a hint of WaMu in it. Cons: Tell me you did not use egg-mix to make my eggs! The ambience may be too new for some accustomed to old school grime on the wall diners. Hint- come eat here and contribute to any future grime. To sum it up. A neighborhood diner that rises from the ashes of the financial crisis. You can debate this issue over coffee. Maybe we need more diners and less banks, I'd raise a cup of joe to that.

Setup: My wife and I were looking for a cheap brunch after a night of bar hopping.  I've been here twice now and both times I've been very happy with the food. It's by no means gourmet, and I tend to get the least healthy things on the menu (Mediterranean Skillet), but the food always hits just right. The coffee is good and the pancakes are surprisingly good as well. I'm not pancake expert, but I thought they tasted better than average. I'd like to extend this review a bit, but this is your average, good but not great breakfast joint. Great for a groups of friends since it's not too loud.

When we moved into the neighborhood we had all of one opportunity to dine at the Alps. Then it closed, and there was much weeping and gnashing of teeth. It seemed like the old diners closed one by one after we moved in--though I don't think it was cause and effect. Vosnos Restaurant and Pancake House... the Blue Angel (I think that was the name) on Irving Park Rd., and so on. All gone. What was a hipster to do if he wanted a simple breakfast of bacon, eggs, and pancakes on a Saturday or Sunday morning. Losing the Alps was a real heartbreaker though. Thank goodness it came back. And the food is as comforting and tasty as ever. Nice decor and friendly staff too. Great place to take our toddler as well. a trip to the Alps is always in order!

Excellent chocolate chip pancakes! Yes I'm almost 30 and still eat chocolate chip pancakes, but don't judge! Had the corned beef skillet. The meat was good and the eggs were cooked perfect. The peppers were the freshest I had ever eaten at a diner. I was pleasantly surprised at how fresh and tasty everything was. And the service was top notch as well. This is my new go to spot for breakfast.

Very Hospitable, Pancakes that melt in your mouth, Service that puts other Diners & Pancake houses to shame...a Feta/Spinach omelette that tasted so fresh, was served hot and came out quickly along with bottomless coffee....plus a no-need-to-rush attitude, take your time!  Alps is the best!!!

Waitress "Mo" is hilarious and was the highlight of the experience. I felt like she was straight out of a sitcom, like Alice. She had a funny sarcasm and wit about her. The experience, overall, was great. The food -OK. It wasn't bad, it was just OK -similar to other places I have been to. I guess I was expecting something more "wow". I had heard they were "really good" so I was expecting something different or unique but it was just some good / OK food. I will say, the potato pancakes were made fresh and were very good. Everything else OK. I did enjoy the attentiveness of Mo and the ambiance so it's likely I will be back to try something a little more adventurous than the standard breakfast and see if they can "wow" me!
Good food, fast, good service, and affordable. What else do you want in a diner.

Maybe it's just a Midwest thing, but I love Diners. There is nothing pretentious about a diner. You can dress in a casual manner and just relax.  This was our second attempt to dine at the Alps west. The first time we went there, the hostess told us that it would be an hour wait. There are very few things that I will wait an hour for, and breakfast isn't one of them. So, on a Saturday morning with visions of Eggs and Toast in my head, we made our way back to the Alps West. To my pleasant surprise, there was no wait. From the moment we were seated, I felt like a kid at Christmas. The smell of fresh brewed coffee was in the air and I saw plates filled with Breakfast goodies being delivered to the tables around us. The Alps offers a large selection of items that will please just about anybody.  After a long debate (all of about 4 minutes),  I decided to go with the Chorizo Omelet. Chorizo is a gift from the Mexican Gods that I rarely turn down. When my plate was served, I almost shed a tear. The Chorizo was bulging from the Eggy dish, and the hash browns were crisped to perfection. The meal tasted even better than it looked. All I needed was a few ounces of hot sauce to make this meal perfect.  The bottom line on the Alps West is this. If you are looking for the perfect weekend breakfast at a affordable price, get your ass down to the Alps. The service is wonderful and the Coffee is hot and delicious.

Hey, to me, a diner's a diner.  Basic, fast, cheap.  I have learned not to expect much.  And I actually had not expected much of the new Alps, but after going there twice and being turned away (one because the wait was around 45 minutes and the other because we didnt realize they closed at 3pm), I was suddenly stricken with the NEED to go there.  Sort of like this juvenile reaction to not receiving a desired toy... WANT, NEED, HAVE TO HAVE.  So finally, on a remarkably crap-tastic Saturday, with a windy, wet snow falling at a rapid pace, we took my out of town friend and attempted the Alps for the third time.   We were seated almost immediately and presented with a migraine inducing menu...so many choices!  I finally decided on their take of huevos rancheros, which came with warm corn tortillas and hashbrowns.  Not the most authentic dish, but prepared well and tasty.  The service was good and they kept us in water and coffee the whole time.  I also appreciated the design of the place, which was clean and modern and not pink and hokey like some diners I have been to.  I guess the third time really is the charm.  I liked the Alps and would not hesitate to return.  Also the fact that it is convenient to where I live is a big bonus!

I'm a bit biased as this is quite close to home, but it's a diner and is what it is. The people here are quite friendly, except the cashier when you block his payment line. We waited about 10 minutes to be seated on a Sunday morning. Getting our food did take longer, and I never did get my coffee. Also my "healthy choice" breakfast ended up having hashbrowns instead of fruit. But damn the egg white omelet was huge! We'll be back... maybe because we live so close. Maybe because the food is quite delish when you do finally get it.

Much better than WaMu.  I was really pissed when Alps closed down to be replaced by a dying bank, and I waited eagerly for a restaurant to open up again when I heard the news of Washington Mutual's death.  It's your typical family breakfast place and much more modern than the old Alps. I have yet to recieve bad food, bad service, or anything to complain about. They have a good early bird special, kick-ass location, balls to the wall poached eggs and it's quite possibly the best thing that's happened to the neighborhood in the last 3 years.

This neighborhood desperately needs a breakfast spot, so when Alps reopened in late 2009, it was a blessing.  I am thankful just to have a place to walk to in the morning to get some quick eats.  However, the servers do come off as overwhelmed, and the kiddie pancakes were possibly microwaved.  My dishes were typical of diners, not that I care to admit I eat in them often, but the food was edible.  If you need someplace to go that's near by your house and it doesn't need to impress, then this is the place.  I would not ever drive to this place, nor suggest it to friends outside of the neighborhood.

hrm... maybe they cleaned up their act? after reading some of the other reviews i was shocked at the comments about poor service and long waits. i've never had a problem with either. even on a saturday or sunday morning i've always been seated immediately and had fast friendly service. onto the important... they've got skillets and lots of em. the gypsy skillet is my go to breakfast when i can't be bothered to make decisions or try anything new.

I'm really surprised at all the negative reviews! We had a great experience here. We walked in early on a Sunday afternoon and were promptly greeted and seated by a very friendly woman. The place was 3/4 full and very clean.  We were immediately served hot, delicious coffee. Now, I know this doesn't do it for everyone, but I was really pleased they had flavored creamers at the table. Score.  We had typical breakfasts...an omelet and pancakes...and it was delicious. There was so much food, and it was all hot and fresh. The waitstaff was attentive and kept the coffee cup full. When the bill came, it was more than reasonable for all the food we received.  I am very happy to have this place in my neighborhood. But you should stay out. I don't want to have to wait in line.

Placed in a counter seat on a busy Saturday morning.  Waited 15 minutest for coffee and 35-40 minutes for my omelet and toast. When it arrived it was warm, not blazing hot, suggesting to me it had been cooling on a counter somewhere.  I'm pleased to see this location a restaurant again;  the neighborhood needs a good breakfast and lunch place.  But I won't hurry back.

Walked a mile to get here ... Was a lovely walk ... Only to be greeted with the inept "keeper of the names" ... She couldn't read her own list, couldn't advise on a wait time, and was just generally disorganized ... I know it's just recently opened, but the folks running this place look old enough to have been involved in an opening or two in their time ... Floor plan wastes space that could be leveraged for revenue (i.e. shorter wait times, etc) ... Will probably be successful because it's equidistant of two Golden Nuggets ... Might try again, might leave it to those who appreciate chaos

I have been waiting for MONTHS for this place to open, and finally they did!  It was crowded for a Friday morning, and full of children that should have been in school. We were served fresh, hot coffee and water right away. Our server, Jeanne, was attentive and sweet. It was her second day on the job, and some jerk at the table next to us was complaining about his toast incessantly. She handled it with grace.  We ordered the Veggie Skillet for my husband, and I ordered Ladies Special #1 (eggs, pancakes, and toast)! Our food took a while, but they were busy. I loved the extensive menu, and the bright, sunny atmosphere in this Greek-owned restaurant. Our food was solid, decent, and the portions are generous. But, sorry ALPs, the pancakes are better at the G.N. (golden nugget).  I will definitely come back to try a Sassy Salad or something off of the Waist Watchers section. I love restaurants that are Weight Watcher Friendly!!!
